title: Typhoon Hagibis: Everything you need to know as Japan braces for monster storm
text:

Japan is bracing for potentially catastrophic Super Typhoon Hagibis, threatening to be stronger than a monster storm that killed 1,200 people 60 years ago.

Category 4 Hagibis has triggered a mass evacuation and flight cancellations, fears of casualties and widespread damage, and chaos for the Rugby World Cup and Formula One organisers.

Forecasters have warned of devastating winds of up to 135mph, storm surges, giant waves, more than 2ft of rain in 24 hours, flooding and landslides.

Life-threatening Hagibis is expected to be the worst typhoon of 2019 and the most powerful storm to batter Japan in 60 years, forcing Rugby World Cup matches, including England's Pool C showdown with France, to be cancelled.

Here is everything you need to know.

When will Super Typhoon Hagibis hit?

(Image: Infographic PA Graphics)

Hagibis, which means "speed" in the Philippine language Tagalog, was swirling towards Japan on Friday as time began to run out for those making their final preparations to leave or hunker down.

Some places will begin to feel the effects as early as Friday night as rain moves in and winds become stronger.

Hagibis will gradually weaken as it approaches Japan but it could still be an extremely dangerous Category 2 or 3 storm when it possibly makes landfall on the main island of Honshu on Saturday evening.

It is expected to hit the Tokyo area in the evening and a possible near-direct hit on Yokosuka.

The typhoon will track across Japan into Sunday before moving out into the Pacific, but potential impacts such as flooding or power cuts could last days.

How bad is it going to be?

(Image: X01481)

Hagibis is expected to be as strong as Typhoon Ida, which killed 1,200 people in eastern and central Japan in 1958 - and forecasters have warned of catastrophic scenarios.

Winds of about 135mph could cause homes to collapse, according to Japan's Meteorological Agency, which has predicted giant waves, storm surges, record-level rainfall, flooding and landslides.

The typhoon - which was a Category 5 storm with near 160mph winds earlier in the week - could make landfall at the same time as high tide in Tokyo Bay, increasing fears of flooding.

There could be considerable disruption to cities such as Tokyo, Yokohama and Toyota.

How is Japan preparing?

(Image: NASA GODDARD MODIS RAPID RESPONSE/HANDOUT/EPA-EFE/REX)

Forecasters have urged those in the storm's path to flee their homes before it is too late, while those who are hunkering down have been told to stockpile food and supplies in case the disruption lasts several days.

Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has ordered all government departments to prepare for the storm, which has resulted in more than 1,600 flights being cancelled.

ANA cancelled all domestic flights to and from Tokyo's two main airports from Friday afternoon.

Weekend bullet train services between Tokyo and Nagoya in central Japan and most operations between Nagoya and Osaka, in western Japan, have been cancelled.

Train and subway lines in Tokyo are closing and hundreds of shops - including supermarkets - are also shutting.

(Image: AFP/Getty Images)

Some supermarkets ran out of bottled water and batteries. Twitter users posted photographs of bare shelves and traded tips on how to prepare for disruptions to water and power cuts.

Tokyo Disneyland is due to close on Saturday in the first weather-related closure since a snowstorm in 1984.

A number of factories have halted production. They include three belonging to Toyota Motor Corp and Nippon Steel's plant in Kimitsu, which was partially damaged by Typhoon Faxai last month.

Officials in the Chiba prefecture east of Tokyo, which was hit hard by typhoon Faxai a month ago, have told people to prepare supplies of food and water for up to three days.

Many of more than 30,000 houses Typhoon Faxai destroyed or damaged in Chiba last month have yet to be repaired.

Rugby World Cup matches cancelled

(Image: Getty Images)

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

Rugby World Cup games pitting England against France and New Zealand against Italy have been called off, meaning both matches will be considered scoreless draws.

A final decision on Sunday’s games, including a crucial match between hosts Japan and Scotland, will be made that morning.

Scottish Rugby Union chief Mark Dodson said he is ready to launch a legal challenge to prevent organisers cancelling the game - a measure that would almost certainly eliminate the Scots from the competition.

Japanese Formula One Grand Prix organisers cancelled all practice and qualifying sessions scheduled for Saturday, adding that the qualifying round would be held on Sunday, before the final race takes place as planned.

Formula One team bosses backed the decision.
description: Super Typhoon Hagibis could be a major disaster with 135mph winds and up to 2ft of rain, triggering mass evacuations and the cancellation of England's Rugby World Cup match
authors: Nasa Goddard Modis Rapid Response Handout Epa-Efe Rex
